awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Electrochemical Oxidation Water Treatment Process for Harmful Algal Blooms
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is mitigate the effects of harmful algae blooms (HABs), which are a threat to human and wildlife health and result in significant financial loss in areas such as recreational and commercial fishing operations.  Increasing global temperatures and continued use of nutrient-rich fertilizers are likely to exacerbate HAB concerns in the future.  The approach developed here to address these toxic blooms may reduce the likelihood of health-related problems associated with HABs by rapidly eliminating surface blooms via an electrochemical oxidation technology.  Environmental consulting and remediation companies represent the likely first customers for the technology while municipalities and lake associations are important stakeholders.  Through this project, potential customers, partners, and stakeholders will be engaged to understand how HABs are currently managed, how environmental remediation companies engage their customers, and how the supply chain for environmental remediation equipment is structured.

This I-Corps project develops a harmful algae bloom (HAB) mitigation technology for treating transient HABs.  The temporal occurrence of HABs causes extra challenges for HAB mitigation as traditional efforts involve the use of hydrogen peroxide, aeration for biostimulation, or algae harvesting processes, all of which require the use of pesticide permits which are site and time specific.  The developed technology is based on electrochemical oxidation (EO) techniques that rapidly remove algae and cyano toxins without the addition of chemicals. Thus, no pesticide permits are required, allowing for rapid deployment of the technology to mitigate a HAB before it causes beach closures.  The process consists of a power supply, a generator, and a set of electrodes with specialized electrode coatings.  The unique electrode composition results in a significant energy savings compared to traditional EO processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through the I-Corps Program the project, team interviewed 100 stakeholders throughout the U.S. about harmful algae blooms (HABs).  Results from the interviewed allowed the project team to refine ResET Water?s value proposition. 

The first value proposition is ?avoid 90% of recreational downtime by remediating blooms within a day of observation.? Of the interviews, 34 mentioned recreation as a main concern and 19 mentioned health of the community members or pets as a concern. When a bloom occurs, the longer it exists on a body of water the more it affects recreation. In addition, the longer it exists the more likely it is for community members or pets to encounter the bloom and experience detrimental health effects.

The second value proposition was ?increase lakefront property values by 2-3% by removing 90% of blooms each year.? Several lake associations mentioned declining property values. By reducing recreational downtime and cleaning up blooms before they cause negative public perception, ResET Water?s technology could meet customers? needs and halt the declining property values.

How the technology is designed and intended be used also plays a major role in interest and consideration. Structured lake associations responded positively to the idea of boat mounted systems they could own and operate, preferring something that is small enough to mount on existing pontoon boats and easy for members to use. Unstructured lake associations were more interested in hiring out a service to clean the bloom or renting an existing boat with the technology already on it. All of these activities will be important considerations for ResET Water when designing their technology, marketing strategy, and customer acquisition tactics.

From the interviews, we learned that the scale of blooms tends to be small to medium in size, 75% of lake associations responded either small or medium. This is an advantage to our technology, which is most effective for small to medium sized blooms. Length of blooms are variable, but 20% of the reported blooms lasted less than 2 days indicating a need for a quick response time for remediation.

A key consideration for determining commercialization of the technology is willingness to pay. Lake associations were asked what their willingness to pay for the mitigation of their HAB problem. Of the 58 lake associations interviewed, only 23 provided a dollar amount for willingness to pay. While this is a small sample size, the data does provide some key insight. A main question was whether lake association structure affected willingness to pay. There is a clear difference in willingness to pay based on organization type. Non-structured lake associations have a lower average willingness to pay than structured lake associations and water districts. The average across all organization types for willingness to pay was $198,478.

The first recommendation for a technology adjustment relates to the scalability of the system. While scalability was mentioned in the interviews by lake associations as a concern, the scale of the current system is adequate for the needs of our target customer. Of the 58 lake associations interviewed, 38.16% experience small-scale blooms and 36.84% experience medium scale blooms. The current prototype for ResET Water has the capacity to treat 100 gallons per minute and is designed to handle small-scale blooms. Determining cleanup times of small-scale blooms however should be determined to verify the prototype has an adequate capacity.  

Cost reduction of the system must also be pursued to increase lake associations? ability and willingness to pay for new technology. Cost was the most cited criterion for product selection, as demonstrated by the qualitative data. While structured lake associations have a higher willingness to pay, the often obtain funding from multiple sources that may not be consistent. More data on willingness to pay is required to calculate an accurate range of willingness to pay to determine a price point for the technology. Even without an accurate range of willingness to pay, ResET Water should take action to source materials that reduce the overall cost of the device without compromising the effectiveness of HAB removal.

Based on the interviews conducted and quantitative analysis, there are minimal technology adjustments for ResET Water. The current capacity is adequate to target small-scale blooms, the device is easy to use, and the company has already begun exploring options to reduce the cost of the technology.

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2023
Modified by: Stefan J Grimberg
